status_notes: Case Noted. Dear Constituent,. Thank you for your comments regarding roadway safety on L Street in South Boston.  Your correspondence has been forwarded to the attention of the Boston Transportation Department for review. . Over the next several weeks, the City of Boston’s Transportation and Public Works Departments will be working with the South Boston community to identify and implement changes aimed at improving roadway safety along L Street.  The City has started making short-term investments to calm speeds and improve intersections, and these will continue through the fall.  Long-term advancements will focus on additional upgrades to L Street as well as the larger City Point neighborhood of South Boston. . An initial inspection of the intersection showed traffic-related pavement markings and signage in the vicinity of L Street and East 6th Street to be in good condition.  Although speed was determined not to have been a factor in the recent crash at the intersection of L Street and East 6th Street, the City has installed a speed radar sign on L Street inbound at the approach to East 6thStreet to further remind drivers to drive slowly and proceed with caution in this dense residential neighborhood.  A speed radar sign on L Street outbound, also at the approach to East 6th Street, will be installed shortly.  In addition, yield lines will soon be painted on L Street at both approaches to East 6th Street to supplement the existing pedestrian crosswalks. . Mayor Walsh and BTD have long been committed to improving safety on L Street and the surrounding vicinity.  Updated traffic counts are currently being taken on L Street and they will be used to inform a long term plan. . Safety for all users of Boston’s streets has always been, and will continue to be, the first priority of the Boston Transportation Department.  Significant work is accomplished every day by BTD and the Public Works Department to ensure roadway safety in South Boston and every other neighborhood in the City and this effort will persist.  Safe, reliable and equitable travel on Boston’s streets is our goal. . Thank you for your concern.

description:
Homeless people and drug addicts are living, littering and basically destroying the outside of a public school in Boston. No one has created a systematic plan to keep the area free of this disgrace. Children and camps are consistently heading to the Comminity Pool as well as the playground across the street where litter , clothing and needles are found consistently. 
I am a former employee of this school and this mess would never be tolerated in my small suburban town I live in. 
The police, community leaders, bps, mayor and facilities management team need to come together to find a permanent solution to this travesty. At one time this was an award winning School and I find this situation absolutely unacceptable and wouldn’t be tolerated in another area of town (s). Today a random EMT driver graciously went above and beyond to pick up the needles. Then a city crew came to clean sidewalk and finally a facilities crew came to clean outside school. It is clean now but won’t be 24-48 hours from now. I hope the city departments can come up with a plan to prevent or systematically clean up this area regularly before this dire situation ends up on the local news channels.  
The user entered the address: 150 Norfolk Avenue, Roxbury, Massachusetts to see more details visit: http://seeclickfix.com/issues/4752726

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our safety issues map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. . Before excavating in Massachusetts, it?s the law to call dig safe so that out all the underground utilities are marked out with paint. . This allows the contractor to dig safely and not to hit an underground utility line such as the gas main. . It is rightfully so a mandatory requirement. . The City does shares your frustration that after the work is complete the paint could be being viewed as graffiti by the public. . We have reached out to the utility companies asking if they could develop a paint that wore off more quickly. . Obviously the paint needs to stay visible while the work takes place. . Because there is so much excavation going on in the City, if we require a utility to power wash off a dig safe marking, we may be washing off new dig safe markings for another ticket called in for a new excavation. . This could cause a contractor to inadvertently hit an underground pipe causing a possible Public Safety situation and creating a liability issue for the City. . It?s a dilemma that we are working on; it?s not an easy remedy .. However it's important to remember that Public Safety trumps all. . Eventually the paint should wear off over time. . If the markings are still there in the next 60 -90 days please contact my office. . Sincerely,. . Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. The bike facilities on Main Street (two-way portion) in Charlestown required a revised design based on the available width on the roadway. Unfortunately, the available width changed at various points along the corridor. The bike lanes that were there were not compliant with a minimum size that is permitted by safety guidelines for lanes next to parked vehicles. Efforts were made to keep as much as possible of the bike lane continuous on either side of the street. Where the lanes needed to be removed/modified, sharrows will be installed to indicate that the lane is to be shared by both motorists and cyclists. Constraints did exist, however, with maintaining a minimum width for the travel lanes (a key bus route also), as well as needing to keep the existing curbside resident parking.

Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the gas trench needing the top course placed as being the responsibility of Feeney Brothers. Note: The National Grid strike resulted in all contract work for main installation to be suspended and that is what you have observed the trench left low for the top course. We have told National Grid that we need the top course placed as soon as possible. We understand that the gas main work itself is still on hold. You should see the topping of the trenches shortly. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. . We apologize for the inconvenience. . Sincerely,. . Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
